narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: the bulk of this course goes into the projects you do for clients in DC. this is a TON of work, but worth it if you get a project and/or client you want.

the course is unorganized and the requirements to complete not one but two clinical policy research projects is overly demanding and unnecessary. i would recommend that students only be required to complete one research project, which would result in better quality work and a better experience for students and their clients.

I really enjoyed this course and learned an enormous amount. Jim Lyons is a great guy and has a lot of wonderful stories to tell, and brought in some great guest speakers. However class time is really not the valuable part of the course, it's the two projects that you work on with outside clients and with Jim's guidance. Jim provides clear and sufficient advice on these projects and pushes you to do well, but otherwise you're on your own to research and answer a policy question posed by an outside client. This means that there was almost no work for the class before spring break, as we were choosing projects, making contact with our clients, and dawdling on research. It's hard to stop researching and start writing, and so the workload over the last three weeks of the semester was absolutely unbearably tremendous--allnighter after allnighter to get the work produced. The experience of giving the presentations, however, was great (I rated the field trip organization as low despite terrific effort by Kate because the first trip to DC coincided with Snowmaggedon and everything got canceled and communication was really tough).

Question 1-There could have been better reading materials regarding the discussion subjects for each class. A well structured class could have tremendous benefits on student projects. Readings could have been selected to prepare the students for invited speakers. There is a lot of potential here.
4 - Two projects is overwhelming, particularly when responsibilities are not shared equally due to differences in expertise.

This course was all about the client projects, which were incredibly valuabe. First of all, Jim was able to put together a long list of fascinating projects with various DC-based organizations and agencies -- an impressive task that few other professors would ever be able to do. The two projects I worked on were related to interesting and timely natural resource policy issues. It was a treat to work for a client on a real-world problem when most of my other courses are obscured in academic abstraction. I greatly enjoyed both of my groups and both of my clients. I loved this course and would recommend it to anyone.
Experience. Developing relationships with great organizations. Interesting projects. Professor's connections are fantastic.
the projects. they were also the worst
The assignments, they were the whole class
Learning the process and then getting deeply involved in researching substantive policy questions. And getting to network with NGO clients.
The experience of working for a client in a specific project. This was invaluable. I would recommend this course to any one who is thinking about policy research or consulting.
Practical experience.
Working in groups with real clients is an incredible experience.
getting to connect directly with policy organizations in DC. this is great for future networking and gaining some more real world experience with policy-type work.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: somehow forcing students to do more of their projects in the first half of the semester so they don't take over our lives at the end

I don't feel that the instructor is entirely invested in the students' having a positive experience. I also think that requiring multiple trips to DC for client meetings is totally unnecessary. One trip at most should be all that is required of the students.

It would be great if it could get moving faster at the beginning of the semester. I did not end up meeting either of my clients in person at the beginning of the work, and ended up feeling that while it would have been great to do so we did findwith connecting by phone. Maybe the semester could be kicked off on the phone so that scheduling is easier and projects can start sooner?
Reading assignments for specific classes, and the structure of class time, can be improved upon.
One project would be better.
It needs to be more than 3 credits...it is a ton of work to do an adequate job on 2 projects
the workload was a lot for this class - it was hard to balance having two projects and do a good job on both.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Very timely with comments on draft work. He also always had extremely valuable insights and added very much to my projects.
n/a
Lots of help from the TA. The instructor lives in DC and was available by Email and could trouble shoot with clients, so I guess everyone was pretty available overall.
The TA was stressed out by her responsibilities, and the instructor didn't answer email.
Great. I worked with both the prof and the TA and both were very helpful for both specific and general questions.
Kate was great! Prompt with her answers.
Most work was done directly with the clients and instructor/ta coordinated meetings/timelines.

TA was accessible, though she didnt seem to enjoy organizing things for the class.The instructor seemed to give more attention to certain projects he found interesting, and less to others. He also took forever to reply to emails.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm trying to do more policy
This is a capstone course in every sense. It combines elements of many other courses and smashes them in to two projects

This course was wonderful for my overall program. I am interested in pursuing policy analysis and policy making, and have never done a project like this before. I felt it was great real-world experience and excellent professional preparation.
I am pursuing the professional MEM degree and this course helps practice and develop professional skills. I got to work on climate projects, my program focus.
I am interested in policy related work - so it was great. Its also great if you want to gain consulting experience.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I think clinic and practicum courses are the most valuable courses at F&ES. The available projects for this class were all fascinating. Anyone with an interest in agriculture should take this class because the professor was USDA undersecretary.
see 15
The instructor and the assignments
I wanted to be sure that working in policy issues in DC was not for me, and now I am sure of that.
See above.
I wanted to take a project course to get experience with the policy arena in DC.
Practical experience. Interesting clients and projects.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes. The projects were extremely engaging and I am very proud of my products.
pretty much
yes
Yes. Again, not because of class time so much, but because of the nature of the assignment/projects.
With the exception of the structure of class discussions, yes.
Yes, but was more work than I expected
Yes
Yes, though I wish the projects were more manageable/feasible given the time constraints of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
sort of
yes
Yes

I was not sure exactly what to expect. I enjoyed my projects tremendously. I had strong motivated teams, and great mentors in the organizations I worked with. I would recommend this course to other students.
Yes, but I was hoping to get a job out of it too! No luck there.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The projects were both richer because of the amount of work we were able to do as a team. One team member struggled with English, which was occasionally a hindrance.
PICK YOUR GROUPS CAREFULLY. they will make or break your semester.
Group work was essential for this class, the workload would be unmanageable withoutit. Working in groups is what you will be doing in a real work env.

The fact that we each had two groups to manage was REALLY frustrating. Students should be required to pass some sort of writing test before taking classes like this. I had one team mate who really couldn't write and couldn't hold up his end of the bargain. This put a lot of pressure on the rest of the team.
Advantages--better quality and more depth to the projects.Disadvantage--group writing and review takes a lot more time than working on your own.
Both of my teams were fantastic. Very diverse backgrounds and interests, but committed, extremely responsive, collaborative rapport from all team members.
Lack of expertise of partners. Took on lots of responsibility vis-a-vis my partners. Again, I could have handled this for one project, but two was overwhelming.
Real life experience working for clients as a team rather than individual. It can be very difficult but also very rewarding
team member evaluations should have been conducted! Some people do more work than others. The prof/TA/client do not necessarily know about the internal workings of a group.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Front-load your projects. Try to get as much done as early as possible.
pick groups&projects carefully. Push jim to spend more time on choosing projects&groups.
This class is a lot of work! 2 full projects for real clients who may or may not realize you are in school with other classes to attend. This should be a 4 or 6 credit class.
Start and finish researching early!

Be very careful when choosing your project, and your team members. Although I had a great experience with my teams, I did hear from other class members that not all team members were as responsive and collaborative. Choose an organization that you might see yourself working with. Since there are two projects, it may be helpful to pick a project you are very familiar with, and a project you are not very familiar with, to both further your expertise and try something completely different.
Be prepared to work a lot, and dont just pick projects that look cool, pick TEAM members that you trust have the capacity and will to contribute as much as you.
It is a lot of work so make sure at least one of your other classes has a relatively light load. Pick your teams/topics carefully as that will make or break the experience. This was a great class.

Choose two projects you are passionate about or really interested in. Don't base the decision solely on where you want to build connections.If you have a choice between different teams - choose people who are reliable and hardworking.
